Award.AwardTitle: Travel support for DAMOP2014 for US students, June 2-6, 2014
Award.AbstractNarration: This award provides travel support for student participation in the 45th Annual Meeting of the American Physical Society Division of Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics (APS-DAMOP) to be held June 2-6, 2014 in Madison, Wisconsin. Support is provided only for US students (students enrolled in US universities). The Conference has grown in recent years and attracts over one-thousand participants. Covering all the major areas of atomic, molecular and optical physics, this conference series is of outstanding importance to the vitality of atomic, molecular, and optical physics in the United States. This Conference offers an opportunity for students to present their research results and to interact with senior scientists primarily from the United States, but also the broader international community. In addition, a one-day graduate student symposium in conjunction with the conference has been organized to introduce students to cutting-edge topics in atomic, molecular, and optical physics. The support of students through this award makes a substantial contribution to the education and training of future scientists. Students who graduate with a background in atomic, molecular, and optical physics acquire a broad range of knowledge and skills that enable them to contribute to progress in many areas of science and technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award provided travel support for students at U.S. Universities to attend the 2014 annual meeting of the division of Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics (DAMOP) of the American Physical Society.  The Conference is an official meeting of the American Physical Society with a total budget exceeding $300,000. Support is needed to ensure the participation of a large and diverse group of researchers, and to help foster the interchange of scientific information among young scientists. Because of its influence on the productivity and up-to-date awareness of individual investigators, this conference series is of outstanding importance to the vitality of atomic, molecular, and optical physics in the United States. This Conference offers an opportunity for students to present their research results and to interact with senior scientists primarily from the United States, but also the broader international community. In addition, a one-day graduate student symposium in conjunction with the conference has been organized to introduce students to cutting-edge topics in atomic, molecular, and optical physics. Student travel awards were made in the amount of $500; funds for 24 such awards were granted from the experimental atomic, molecular, and optical physics program from the National Science Foundation. The support of students through this grant makes a substantial contribution to the education and training of future scientists. Students who graduate with a background in atomic, molecular, and optical physics acquire a broad range of knowledge and skills that enable them to contribute to progress in many areas of science and technology.
